Posts.Content: Sleeping on back or side at night and repressing thoughts about sex are important until catheter is removed. Doctor may want to examine urine after if is removed and while you are still at the office. Be sure and take the portable bottle as you may need it before you can make it home. I was fortunate after surgery at Cleveland Clinic in 2008 -- no significant leakage and no need for pads.
Posts.Title: Home after my daVinci

Posts.Title: Home after my daVinci

Posts.Content: Has anyone else been frustrated with the term PSA doubling? I would think going from 0.04 to 0.08 is not the same as going from 4.0 to 8.0, yet all the references caution patients to monitor the PSA velocity. My PSA has been steady at 0.1 for six months after being non-detectable (<0.03) for the first 3 years following surgery. Had positive margins but the prostate gland is completely gone. And is there any benefit in seeing a medical oncologist instead of a radiology oncologist (already consulted and raring to go with radiation therapy) about this? Thank you.
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed with prostate cancer in May 2008 (age 54) after PSA increased from 1.5 to 9.3 in 2 years (coincided with 25 lbs weight gain.) DRE was negative, then biopsy (12 samples) at Cleveland Clinic found Gleason 3+3 in left mid and left apex. Robot-assisted (DaVinci) prostate surgery performed at the Cleveland Clinic July 2008. Recovered very quickly. Pathology report confirmed adenocarcinoma with Gleason 3+3, Stage pT2+ (extraprostatic extension undetermined due to incision at site of positive surgical margins.) PSA tested every 3 months <0.03 until 11/2011 (0.04), rising on 10/2012 (0.06), on 01/2013 (0.09), and steady since then at 0.10. Currently weighing external radiation therapy and long term side effects. Bone scan and CT scans in 03/2013 both negative. Other: Vasectomy at age 47; Vitamin E (400 iu/day) therapy for treating inflammation at age 52; no family history of prostate cancer.
Posts.Title: PSA Velocity after RP - What is normal?

Posts.Content: Thanks to you both, Fairwind and Highlander. Did consult with a hemo/onco specialist (referred by my PCP) who said every patient/cancer/treatment case is unique. He offered no more helpful advice beyond very close monitoring, then directly billed me an outrageous sum for an initial consultation. It was my costly mistake as I found this doctor did not accept any insurance plan even though the receptionist copies your insurance card. Got so mad that I returned directly to "GO" and started all over. Found another book that identified a website for a San Diego-based Informed Prostate Cancer Support Group (ipcsg.org) that taught me many things that I have not read before anywhere. For example: when did radiation get started; why did surgery become more prominent, when did nerve-sparing surgery start; why surgery patients have urinary and sexual side effects; why do radiation patients have rectal side-effects; and most importantly, what improvements have been made in recent years to diminish these side effects. Includes videos from Dr. Snuffy Myers that offers helpful critiques of therapy, studies, etc. It's a shame that the news media doesn't have the time or the expertise to do a better job of objectively reporting on cancer treatments. The lack of really good information fuels the quack medicine fads.
